summary: Alan G. Sentinella was a retired FBI Special Agent who testified before the Senate Select Committee (SSC) in May and June of 1975. His testimony primarily concerned FBI investigations into Martin Luther King Jr., the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC), and Stanley Levison. The documents summarizing his testimony detail the FBI's surveillance activities, including electronic surveillance, and their investigations into alleged communist connections. Sentinella's testimony provides insights into the FBI's operational policies and objectives during this period. The documents consistently refer to his testimony before the SSC regarding the aforementioned investigations.
significance: While the provided documents do not directly link Alan G. Sentinella to the JFK assassination, his testimony before the Senate Select Committee (SSC) sheds light on the FBI's activities and surveillance practices during the 1960s and 1970s. This context may be relevant to understanding the broader political and investigative landscape surrounding the JFK assassination, particularly concerning potential surveillance of individuals or groups of interest.
